p: Nevertheless, it is plausible to assume that current consumption patterns in low income socioeconomic groups are bound to have improved in terms of caloric intake ever since the survey was conducted in 2008â€“2009, considering that GDP per capita and purchase power has grown considerably, together with a significant reduction in poverty and extreme poverty rates [ 67]. The distribution of food consumption in these social groups shows that access to certain food products, mainly animal protein and fruit, is an important challenge from a nutritional and health perspective. However, from an environmental approach these consumption patterns should be seen as having promising characteristics, which if managed correctly through policy actions, could mitigate the increase in red meat consumption and other high carbon products that is expected when purchase power increases.
